sentences.text: Indirect presidential elections were held in Trinidad and Tobago on 20 January 2023.

references.text: <ref>[https://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/news/20221227/trinidad-tobago-elect-new-president-jan-20 Trinidad & Tobago to elect new president Jan 20]</ref>

sentences.text: On 5 January 2018, the name of Paula-Mae Weekes, a judge of the Turks and Caicos Islands Court of Appeal, was put forward by the People's National Movement|PNM government of Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago|Prime Minister Keith Rowley in hopes of reaching a consensus with the United National Congress|UNC-led parliamentary opposition of Kamla Persad-Bissessar, which later indeed endorsed her nomination as well. As Weekes was the only nominated candidate on election day, she was deemed elected without the need for a vote. Paula-Mae Weeks thus became the List of elected and appointed female heads of state and government|first woman to take office as president of Trinidad and Tobago on 19 March 2018.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.trinidadexpress.com/20180105/news/pms-wise-choice |title=Trinidad Express Newspapers: News | PM's WISE CHOICE |accessdate=2018-02-18 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180107061126/http://www.trinidadexpress.com/20180105/news/pms-wise-choice |archivedate=7 January 2018 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

sentences.text: The People's National Movement|PNM government nominated Christine Kangaloo, the President of the Senate of Trinidad and Tobago|President of the Senate. The opposition United National Congress|UNC declined to endorse her candidacy on the grounds that she was an active member of the government party and so have nominated their own candidate, Israel Raja-Khan. It's the first time in more than two decades that a presidential election took place without a consensus candidate.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web|date=2023-01-07|title=She's a PNM politician|url=https://trinidadexpress.com/news/local/she-s-a-pnm-politician/article_cbdf816c-8e2f-11ed-9f12-1bffc6c051d6.html|website=Trinidad Express Newspapers|Trinidad Express|language=en-US}}</ref>

sentences.text: To win the election a candidate must gain a plurality of votes cast, whereby a quorum comprising the Speaker of the House of Representatives, 10 Senators and 12 other member of the House of Representatives must be met for the election to be considered valid. If only one candidate should be nominated to run in the election, he or she shall be considered to have been elected president without the need for a vote to take place.
*Christine Kangaloo, President of the Senate of Trinidad and Tobago|President of the Senate (2015-2023)

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web|date=2023-01-07|title=FROM RED HOUSE TO PRESIDENT'S HOUSE|url=https://trinidadexpress.com/news/local/from-red-house-to-president-s-house/article_780064d4-8e30-11ed-aa20-0360332a3440.html|website=Trinidad Express Newspapers|Trinidad Express|language=en-US}}</ref>
